docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate Finance Committee debated Tuesday, and then voted down, amendments by Senators John D. Rockefeller IV of West Virginia and Charles E. Schumer of New York, both Democrats, which had proposed two different approaches to a government-run public insurance option that would be offered in competition with commercial insurance plans. The committee's chairman, Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, was among those voting against the amendments. In response to live coverage on the Prescriptions blog by Katharine Q. Seelye and news reports during the day by David M. Herszenhorn, readers of the blog posted hundreds of comments. Here is a sampling, in many cases condensed from longer postings.
docs.abstract: Sampling of reader blogs commenting on rejection of amendments to health care legislation that would have added public option (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Members of Congress often spend their time wrestling with two distinct questions. Will it work? Can it pass? Of course, it's a basic order of operations that if a bill can't pass, it can't work.
docs.abstract: Senate Finance Committee chairman Max Baucus and Senate Health Committee chairman Tom Harkin comment on recent votes striking two amendments to health care legislation that would have added public option (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Uwe E. Reinhardt, a professor of health economics at Princeton University, researches international health care systems. He spoke with the Prescriptions contributor Anne Underwood about the German system. The full transcript is available online. Here is an excerpt: Q:Is it true that the concept of health insurance originated in Germany?

headline.main: HOW THEY DO IT OVER THERE

headline.main: An Inconvenient Truth: It Can't Work if It Can't Pass

docs.abstract: For the Democrats on health legislation, only what has a chance of passing is what has a chance of working.

docs.lead_paragraph: The left, right, center and all around weighed in on the Senate Finance Committee's defeat of two versions of a public health insurance option. Late in the day, it's still one of the hottest topics whipping around the blogosphere, news and cable TV.

headline.main: BlogTalk: Public Option, Acorn and the Children

docs.abstract: The health care bill remains the No. 1 topic, but everything else seems in play.
docs.snippet: The health care bill remains the No. 1 topic, but everything else seems in play.

byline.original: By KATE PHILLIPS and MARIA NEWMAN

docs.lead_paragraph: Right-wing and antigovernment activists -- a few of them wielding not only signs but even loaded firearms -- have organized some of the angry protests surrounding the health care debate. But in Midtown Manhattan on Tuesday morning, a different sort of health care protest took place, led by left-leaning groups who accused insurers of greed and called for nationwide, single-payer health insurance.

headline.main: 17 Held in Protest Outside Health Insurer's Offices

docs.abstract: The police said that 17 people were arrested after refusing to leave the lobby of an office building on Park Avenue where the insurance company Aetna has offices.
docs.snippet: The police said that 17 people were arrested after refusing to leave the lobby of an office building on Park Avenue where the insurance company Aetna has offices.

docs.lead_paragraph: Uwe E. Reinhardt is a professor of health economics at Princeton University and a former president of the Association of Health Services Research. He is also a member of the Institute of Medicine of the National Academy of Sciences, a board member of the Journal of the American Medical Association and a contributor to The Times's Economix blog. His research has compared health care in the United States to that in other countries, including his native Germany. He spoke with freelance writer Anne Underwood.
docs.abstract: In Germany, birthplace of social health insurance, public and private systems co-exist. Coverage is universal, and medical expenses are relatively low.
docs.snippet: In Germany, birthplace of social health insurance, public and private systems co-exist. Coverage is universal, and medical expenses are relatively low.
